sub_title: University Senior Lecturer at the Leiden University Institute for Area Studies
summary: Award-winning researcher, educator, and writer and an experienced University Lecturer with a demonstrated history of working in higher education. Skilled in Chinese Politics, Lecturing, Media Studies, Macroeconomics, and International Relations Theory. Strong education professional with a Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) focused in Chinese Studies from The University of Sheffield.

awards: [{'title': '2017 Leiden University Teaching Award', 'description': 'The prize is awarded by the Leiden University Students platform (LUS) and supported by the Leiden University Teaching Academy. It is attached to a grant for education development. From the award announcement: \n\'Florian Schneider has earned the title of Leiden University Lecturer of the Year. Sinologist Schneider was nominated by his students and crowned winner of the LUS Teaching Prize at the opening of the academic year by the board of the Leiden University Student Platform (LUS). ‘This is what we look for in a lecturer,’ said LUS chair Ghislaine Voogd during the ceremony in the Pieterskerk. "Schneider is a lecturer who teaches for teaching’s sake. He doesn’t teach because that’s what an academic has to do. Far from it: he sees it as his priority to train the researchers of tomorrow".\'', 'issuer': 'Leiden University Student Platform', 'date': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, {'title': 'EastAsiaNet book prize', 'description': "From the award announcement: \n'The 2014 EastAsiaNet Award for a book was granted to Florian Schneider of Leiden University (Ph.D. from the University of Sheffield) for Visual Political Communication in Popular Chinese Television Series (Leiden: Brill 2012). The jury unanimously lauded this impressive work, which provides a systematic analysis of popular contemporary TV series in China as well as a highly persuasive analysis of their political implications. The book demonstrates how direct official censorship does not explain the common elements of the political discourse found in these programmes. Instead self-censorship, commercial incentives, bias in the rating systems, and so on, are of crucial significance.'", 'issuer': 'EastAsiaNet', 'date': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}]

His research of the past 15 years has i.a. focused on political communication and media in contemporary China.', 'title': 'Director', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 6077, 'name': 'Leiden University', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4D0BAQEFlK1wNecYbA/company-logo_400_400/0/1519855876129?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=KwFN5kUM6lyLgjAXaylWnuNQ6g0XLwvWDjTK4Ug_mEg', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/leiden-university/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Leiden', 'date': {'start': {'month': 10, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'Leiden University', 'description': "Florian Schneider's research interests include questions of governance and public administration in the PRC, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, political communication strategies and political content of popular Chinese entertainment, recent Chinese economic developments, as well as Chinese foreign policy.", 'title': 'University Senior Lecturer', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Leiden University Institute for Area Studies', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'company': 'Leiden University', 'description': "I teach social science courses on Modern China at the BA and MA level, and supervise PhD students. The topics of my classes include: 
- Government and Governance in Modern China, 
- Modern Chinese Economy, 
- From Newspaper to New Media - China's Media System in Transition, 
- Visual Political Communication in China, 
- Political Language and Discourse in Modern China; and others.

My most recent research work focused on the political contents of mainland popular Chinese television series, including their production process, censorship, broadcasting, and audience reception. Methodologically, this work has combined critical discourse analysis, semiotics, and iconography, as well as the analysis of semi-structured qualitative interviews. 

A current project deals with staged mass-media events in mainland China, such as the Beijing Olympic Games Opening Ceremony in 2008, the 60th Anniversary of the People’s Republic of China in 2009, and the Shanghai Expo in 2010. The project explores how the Chinese leadership makes use of such events to promote a national identity and legitimize its own rule. A primary question in this regard is how concepts of tradition and of modernization (or progress) feature into such events, and what impact they have on the interaction between China and other actors in the international community.

My most recent project is entitled Digital Nationalism in China, and is funded by the Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO). Between 2013 and 2016, I will explore how networked actors use Information and Communication Technologies to shape nationalist discourse in the People’s Republic of China, vis-à-vis Japan as foreign Other. This research will be both qualitative and quantitative, and will focus on two cases: the issue networks relating to the 1937 Nanjing Massacre and the Diaoyu/Senkaku Island dispute in the East China Sea.", 'title': 'University Lecturer in the Politics of Modern China', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Leiden University & Brill', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Leiden', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'Leiden University & Brill', 'description': 'The peer-reviewed academic journal Asiascape: Digital Asia explores the political, social, and cultural impact of digital media in Asia.
